Striar v. Luso-American Hospital, 367 Ma.proposition: The duty to exercise reasonable care to protect invitees from dangerous conditions is well-established in Massachusetts and articulated in relevant authorities, including but not limited to:
Striar v. Luso-American Hospital, 367 Ma.case_name: Secretary of Administration & Finance v. Attorney General
Striar v. Luso-American Hospital, 367 Ma.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns the powers and duties of the Massachusetts Attorney General in representing state officers and agencies, and whether he can refuse to prosecute an appeal requested by the Governor and a department head. It does not discuss premises liability, invitees, or any duty to exercise reasonable care to protect invitees from dangerous conditions. Therefore it does not support the proposition cited about the well‑established duty of care to invitees in Massachusetts.
Striar v. Luso-American Hospital, 367 Ma.relevant_excerpt: The Attorney General represents the Commonwealth as well as the Secretary, agency or department head who requests his appearance. G.L.c. 12, § 3. He also has a common law duty to represent the public interest. Attorney Gen. v. Trustees of Boston Elev. Ry. 319 Mass. 642, 652 (1946). Jacobson v. Parks & Recreation Commn. of Boston, 345 Mass. 641, 644 (1963). Thus, when an agency head recommends a course of action, the Attorney General must consider the ramifications of that action on the interests of the Commonwealth and the public generally, as well as on the official himself and his agency.

Sullivan v. Boston & Maine R.R., 383 Mas.proposition: The duty to exercise reasonable care to protect invitees from dangerous conditions is well-established in Massachusetts and articulated in relevant authorities, including but not limited to:

Sullivan v. Boston Safe Deposit & Trust.raw_text: Sullivan v. Boston Safe Deposit & Trust Co., 392 Mass. 821 (1984)
Sullivan v. Boston Safe Deposit & Trust.proposition: The duty to exercise reasonable care to protect invitees from dangerous conditions is well-established in Massachusetts and articulated in relevant authorities, including but not limited to:
Sullivan v. Boston Safe Deposit & Trust.case_name: Certified Corp. v. GTE Products Corp.
Sullivan v. Boston Safe Deposit & Trust.support_reasoning: The opinion is about whether a long-term option to purchase real estate violates the rule against perpetuities; it does not involve premises liability, invitees, or any duty to exercise reasonable care to protect invitees from dangerous conditions. No part of the reasoning or holding addresses tort duties owed to entrants on land. Thus, this case does not support the stated proposition concerning the duty of care to invitees.
Sullivan v. Boston Safe Deposit & Trust.relevant_excerpt: Under the common law in this Commonwealth we adhere to the rule that a contingent future interest is void unless “it must vest, if at all, not later than twenty-one years after some life in being at the creation of the interest.” J.C. Gray, Rule Against Perpetuities § 201, at 191 (4th ed. 1942). See Eastman Marble Co. v. Vermont Marble Co., supra at 152.

Foster v. American Oil Co., 356 Mass. 73.proposition: The duty to exercise reasonable care to protect invitees from dangerous conditions is well-established in Massachusetts and articulated in relevant authorities, including but not limited to:
Foster v. American Oil Co., 356 Mass. 73.support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is from a criminal case involving larceny and grand jury issues, not premises liability or the duty owed to invitees. It does not discuss landowner duties, reasonable care to protect invitees, or any related tort principles. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition about a well-established duty to protect invitees from dangerous conditions in Massachusetts.
Foster v. American Oil Co., 356 Mass. 73.relevant_excerpt: No portion of the opinion discusses premises liability, invitees, or a duty to exercise reasonable care to protect against dangerous conditions; the case instead concerns larceny by false pretences, conspiracy, and grand jury procedure.

Smith v. F.W. Woolworth Co., 21 Mass. Ap.raw_text: Smith v. F.W. Woolworth Co., 21 Mass. App. Ct. 22 (1985)
Smith v. F.W. Woolworth Co., 21 Mass. Ap.proposition: The duty to exercise reasonable care to protect invitees from dangerous conditions is well-established in Massachusetts and articulated in relevant authorities, including but not limited to:
Smith v. F.W. Woolworth Co., 21 Mass. Ap.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with standing of junior lienors to participate in a foreclosure and to attack the validity of a senior mortgage based on fraud, incapacity, or breach of fiduciary duty. It does not concern premises liability, invitees, or any duty to exercise reasonable care to protect invitees from dangerous conditions. Therefore it does not provide authority for the stated Massachusetts duty-of-care proposition.
Smith v. F.W. Woolworth Co., 21 Mass. Ap.relevant_excerpt: The present case spells out a fraud with effect upon the Kirks. “It is doubtless a fraud to enter into a contract with an insane person knowing his condition.” 2 Williston, Contracts § 250, at 79 (3d ed. 1959). Similarly it would be an overreaching amounting to a fraud for an attorney to enter into a contractual arrangement with a client known or suspected to be of limited understanding — unless, indeed, the client had independent representation.

City of.support_reasoning: The opinion is a Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court case, but it deals entirely with allocation of cleanup costs and operator liability under G.L. c. 21E and CERCLA. It does not discuss premises liability, invitees, or a landowner’s common-law duty to exercise reasonable care to protect invitees from dangerous conditions. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the stated proposition about the duty owed to invitees.

Ramos v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co., 41.proposition: The duty to exercise reasonable care to protect invitees from dangerous conditions is well-established in Massachusetts and articulated in relevant authorities, including but not limited to:
Ramos v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co., 41.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns contract negotiations, rights of first refusal, the statute of frauds, and Chapter 93A issues, not premises liability or duties owed to invitees on land. It does not discuss, articulate, or apply any rule about a land possessor’s duty to exercise reasonable care to protect invitees from dangerous conditions. Therefore, it does not support the stated proposition regarding invitee protections in Massachusetts tort law.
Ramos v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co., 41.relevant_excerpt: We note that the contractual commitments in the letter of intent incorporated a binding covenant of good faith and fair dealing. See Anthony’s Pier Four, Inc. v. HBC Assocs., 411 Mass. 451, 473 (1991), and cases cited.
